instructions.title: How to use Bcrypt Hash Generator

steps.title: Enter your password
steps.description: Type or paste the password you want to hash into the input field. The password can be any string of characters.

steps.title: Select cost factor (rounds)
steps.description: Choose a cost factor between 4 and 12. Higher values are more secure but take longer to compute. 10 is recommended for most applications.

steps.title: Generate the hash
steps.description: Click the Generate button to create a bcrypt hash. Each generation produces a unique hash due to the random salt.

steps.title: Verify a hash (optional)
steps.description: To verify a password against an existing hash, enter both values and click Verify. The tool will confirm if they match.

steps.title: Copy the result
steps.description: Copy the generated hash to use in your application's database or configuration file.

proTips: Use cost factor 10 or higher for production passwords
Each hash is unique even for the same password due to random salts
Higher cost factors exponentially increase computation time (each +1 doubles time)
Never store plain-text passwords - always use bcrypt or similar algorithms
The 60-character output includes algorithm identifier, cost, salt, and hash
Test your application's performance with your chosen cost factor before deployment
troubleshooting: Slow generation: Reduce cost factor for faster hashing (but less security)
Hash verification fails: Ensure you're comparing the exact same password (case-sensitive)
Different hashes for same password: This is expected - bcrypt uses random salts
Browser freezes: Very high cost factors (12+) may temporarily freeze the browser
Hash format issues: Valid bcrypt hashes always start with $2a$, $2b$, or $2y$
